attributes.alt: Cover for Sometimes Rain, words by Meg Fleming, and illustrations by Diana Sudyka. The cover art shows two children and a dog running down a hill through the rain.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to review letters
introduce the book with a song about seasons, and introduce vocabulary (
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking the guiding question:
What things do the children do in each season?
Check for understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in text.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Understand and use a growing a number of social studies words.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of common objects.
Invite children to recognize and make the sounds of the letters
Create alliterative sentences for children  to illustrate.
What do we do during different seasons?
In which season does the story you are reading take place?
Choose a season. What clothes will you wear for that season? What will you do?
How many seasons are there? Use connecting cubes to show that number.
What materials would you  use to make an umbrella for  a rainy day?
What blocks will you use to build a house in the snowy woods?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the ask and answer questions Mind Builder and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely and enjoy a conversation about pictures in the book.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Understand and use a growing number of social studies words.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of common objects.
Guide children to hold conversations about the seasons.
Prompt children to ask and answer questions to enhance conversations.
Guide children to express opinion of abilities.
What do we do during different seasons?
Have you read any stories that take place during the summer? What do the characters do?
Pretend you are a building a snowman. What does it look like?
Can you show me three things you might make with sand?
Can you draw a picture of a house in winter and a house in summer? Can you label them?
What materials would you use to make a snowman’s face?
Summer is hot! Can you can write the letters
Can you build a home for one of the animals that we read about in the book? What materials will you use?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build science background,  engage children with an activity, and introduce vocabulary
What do the children wear in different seasons?
Blend two or more syllables to create words; Identify rhyming words.
Show reasonable opinion of own abilities and limitations.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Understand and use a growing number of social studies words.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of common objects; use simple tools to measure and learn about  different objects.
Invite children to create a tree representing one season.
What do we do during different seasons?
What are the seasons like in  your book?
How can you dress for a cool, windy day in fall?
What happens to leaves in the fall? Why do you think the leaves get crunchy?
Can you write or draw about what snow feels like?
Can you make a pumpkin and decorate it?
Butterflies are everywhere!  What letter does butterfly begin with? Draw the letter B and decorate it.
How could you build a tree for squirrels to keep warm in when winter comes?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for The Changing Seasons. The chart shows the four seasons and says, Winter: We skate and sled; Spring: We plant a garden; Summer: We picnic to the buzz of bees: Fall: We watch leaves turn.
Cover for Sometimes Rain, words by Meg Fleming, and illustrations by Diana Sudyka. The cover art shows two children and a dog running down a hill through the rain.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk the seasons, blend words about the seasons, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question:
What do we do during different seasons?
Blend two or more syllables to create words.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information;
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of common objects; use simple tools to measure and learn about  different objects.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Help children sort the picture cards according to the seasons.
Invite children to describe the season and write their ideas.
What do we do during different seasons?
Compare the season in the book to the season we are in now.
Which activity from the chart would you like to do most? Why?
Can you say the seasons in order starting with winter?
Think about what you do during winter. Can you draw and write about it?
Can you use play clay and paper to create a picnic scene like in the Big Chart? What will you make first?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning and the end of the word
?  Try to say the sound and write the letter.
Use blocks to build an igloo for winter! How could you build a bigger one?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to actively engage children to talk about the weather and seasons and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking:
Which season do you like best and why?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and enjoyment.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share and repeat the details in  a text.
Show reasonable opinion of own abilities and limitations.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of common objects; use simple tools to measure and learn about  different objects.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
Which season would you rather spend most of your time in and why?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
What do we do during different seasons?
Which season that we’ve read about is your favorite?
Imagine you are a butterfly in spring! Can you fly from flower  to flower?
Can you use some leaves and twigs to create a bird nest?
Write an email to a friend. Tell what you like best about spring.
Can you draw or use play clay to create the best spring flower?
Can you read an Alphabet Book to a stuffed animal?
Imagine you are creating a garden! How would you make it? What would you plant?
